thread.title: Kiwi event riders in touch after dressage at Les Etoiles de Pau
thread.title_full: Kiwi event riders in touch after dressage at Les Etoiles de Pau

author: Rowan Dixon, NZ Horse & Pony
title: Kiwi event riders in touch after dressage at Les Etoiles de Pau
text:
Kiwi event riders in touch after dressage at Les Etoiles de Pau ROWAN DIXON, NZ HORSE & PONY Last updated 10:09, October 24 2015 Libby Law 
Tim Price and Wesko are the best of the NZ riders after the dressage phase at Pau, sitting fifth 
Germany's Michael Jung has made a storming start to the final big three-day event of the season, at Les Etoiles de Pau in France, to sit first and second after dressage, his two horses separated by just one penalty, despite riding with a broken ankle. 
But New Zealand riders Tim Price and Sir Mark Todd are well in touch after the first phase of the competition, with the cross-country expected to be extremely testing. Price and Wesko are fifth on 40 penalties, 5.5pen behind Jung on Halunke FBW. Only 8.4 penalties separate the top 10. 
Sir Mark Todd is in 14th place on NZB Campino, with a good mark of 43.3, and Jock Paget is 18th on Clifton Signature on 46.9. Although Jonelle Price was 19th on Faerie Dianimo, on 47.7, she has withdrawn before the cross-country. Libby Law 
Michael Jung of Germany holds first place on Halunke FBW, despite riding with a broken ankle 
Of the other New Zealand riders, further down the scoreboard lies Blyth Tait, 28th on Bear Necessity V with 51.3, while Dan Jocelyn, Tim Price on his second ride, and Lucy Jackson are respectively 42nd, 43rd and 46th of the 49-strong field. 
Todd predicts that the water complexes will be influential in tonight's cross-country. "It's a typically French course with forward distances to skinnies and angles, so there are plenty of places to have a silly run-out," he said. 
There are 29 fences on Pierre Michelet's course and 10 of these are combinations. Three are water complexes, which are notoriously tough at Pau. Libby Law 
Jock Paget and Clifton Signature are sitting 18th after dressage 
"The last water complex could be quite a big effort," said Todd. "There's a big drop in and a bounce out of it. And I think the two corners in the preceding water are big. There's lots of places where riders could be caught out." 
Pau is one of the very few major events that Jung, the current Olympic champion, has yet to win, but he looks to have two excellent chances with Halunke, on whom he won the European Champs this year, and his Kentucky winning mare fischerRocana. 
Although he is having trouble walking, Jung is clearly as effective as ever in the saddle. He is using a segway to get around Pau, in the south of France, with his ankle firmly strapped; he chipped a bone in it when he fell in the water at Burghley. Libby Law 
From left: selector Erik Duvander walks the cross-country course with Jonelle Price, Blyth Tait, Dan Jocelyn and Sir Mark Todd 
"My ankle is fixed in place and I can't move it â€” but I can kick," said Michael. "I have to be careful how much walking I do for one more week." Ad Feedback 
British teenager Emily King, daughter of multiple champion Mary King, is sitting pretty at her first four-star, currently holding third place on Brookleigh, and the home side have plenty to cheer about with Astier Nicholas in fourth on Piaf de B'neville. 
Results after dressage 
For more like this, see NZ Horse & Pony magazine, new issue out now 
Michael Jung (GER), Halunke FBW, 34.5, 1; fischerRocana FST, 34.5, 2; Emily King (GBR), Brookleigh, 38.3, 3; Astier Nicolas (FRA), Piaf d'B'neville, 38.5, 4; Tim Price (NZL), Wesko, 40.0, 5; Karim Florent Laghouag (FRA), Entebbe de Hus, 40.6, 6; Tim Lips (NED), Concrex Bayro, 40.9, 7; Paul Tapner (AUS), Indian Mill, 42.3, 8; Jennie Brannigan (USA), Cambalda, 42.6, 9; Bill Levett (AUS), Shanondale Titan, 42.9, 10. - NZ Horse & Pony
